Author: Lidewij van de Peut (24/09/2018)

Main Objects: suluppū (dates)
Comments: The small document lists dates of Murānu and of Bulṭāya, both in year 29. The reverse is blank except for reed marks. The dates could be issued to them or delivered by them.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (24/09/2018)

Main Objects: ebūru (harvest); eqlu (field); gišimmaru (date palm grove); gišimmaru kūṣayu (kūṣayu date palm); gugallu (tax payable to the gugallu); imittu (assessed rent); suluppū (dates); zittu (share)
Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ea-ilūti-bānī, Ilī-bānī and Nanāhu archives.    The last part of the obverse is broken off. The signs are sometimes faint and difficult to read. The beginning of the reverse is broken off.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (24/09/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); kaspu bitqu (silver with 1/8 alloy); qaqqadu (capital); šīmu (price); šūmū (onions, garlic)
Comments: Neither the copy Ner 69 nor the publication Wunsch 1993b, no. 82 do not mention where the reverse of the tablet begins.
Author: Maarja Seire (24/09/2018)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; hubullu (interest); kaspu (silver); ṣēru (steppe); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: This text is a receipt that records the payment of silver as a loan in the steppe. As a date of repayment is also mentioned here, the receipt resembles a promissory note: the recipients of the silver and something else (text broken) are the debtors of Iddin-Marduk, who granted the loan.
Author: Maarja Seire (24/09/2018)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; kaspu (silver)
Comments: Very fragmentary.
Author: Maarja Seire (24/09/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); ṣābu (worker); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: The document records a debt and a payment of a worker/soldier.

Author: Lidewij van de Peut (25/09/2018)

Main Objects: abulli ṣīt Šamši (East Gate); kaspu (silver); mūṣû (exit street); šiddu (wall); sūqu rapšu ša ilāni u šarri (wide street of the gods and the king)
Comments: Sîn-ahhē-bulliṭ/Balāṭu buys half of an exit street that he will share with the sellers.  The tablet is said to be sealed on the upper, and lower edge, and to have nail marks on the left edge, but the copy shows neither seal impressions nor nail markings.
Author: Julia Giessler (25/09/2018)

Main Objects: abulli ṣīt Šamši (East Gate); atru (additional payment); bītu abtu (ruined house); kamaru (ramp); kaspu qalû šibirtu (refined silver in pieces); kunukku (sealed tablet); makkūru (treasury, estate); mūṣû (exit street); mūtaq ilāni u šarri (thoroughfare of the god and the king); mūtaq nišī (thoroughway of the people); qanû (plot of land); šīmu (price); Sîn; sūqu qatnu (narrow street); sūqu rapšu (wide street); ṭuppu (tablet, record)
Comments: Sîn-ahhē-bulliṭ and his brother Sîn-ušallim/Balāṭu//Gallābu buy an old house and a ramp at the East Gate, next to the house of other members of the Gallābu family.  The tablet is said to be sealed on the upper and right edge (line numbering follows the publication), but the copy shows no seal impressions, while nail marks on the right edge are clearly visible.
Author: Julia Giessler (25/09/2018)

Main Objects: akkullātu-formation; ārittu (drain channels); bītu (estate, plot of land); eqlu (field); gišimmaru (date palm); hanšû (hanšû-land); harru (canal); kirû (orchard); maṣṣartu (duty, service; guarding); miṣru (border); mû (water); šissinnu (gardener’s remuneration); suluppū (dates); tamirtu (irrigated farmland); zēru (arable land)
Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ea-ilūti-bānī, Ilī-bānī and Nanāhu archives.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (25/09/2018)

Main Objects: alpu (bull, ox); guqqû (monthly offering); immeru (sheep); karānu (wine, grapes); kurummat šarri (royal ration); šīru (meat); zittu (share)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (25/09/2018)

Main Objects: akalu (bread/food); bītu (house); kaspu (silver); mārūtu (status of adopted son); maškanu (pledge); nikkassu (account); nudunnû (dowry); rīmūtu (gift); šaṭāru (record); šīmu (price); suluppū (dates); tarbûtu (status of foster child); uṭṭatu (barley); zēru zaqpu (land planted with date palms)
Comments: The copy of this tablet is erroneously labeled U. 17238, 11, which is in fact the excavation number of UET 4, 76. The list of tablets in this publication renders the excavation numbers correctly (see UET 4, p. 68).    The obverse of the tablet is badly damaged, but it clearly documents that Nidinti-Sîn/Sîn-ahhē-iddin//Gallābu gives a plot of land to his brothers Sîn-balāssu-iqbi and Sîn-iddin, because he has no son nor daughter.  The tablet is said to be sealed on the upper, lower, and left edge (line numbering follows the publication), but the copy shows no seal impressions, while the nail mark of Nidinti-Sîn is clearly visible.
Author: Julia Giessler (26/09/2018)

Subtype: promissory note, with pledge and interest; promissory note, with pledge and without interest
Main Objects: alpu (bull, ox); Bēl-ālia-ša-Šarrabānu; bīt Ninurta (temple of Ninurta); broken/unclear; ebūr isqi (yield of the prebend); hubullu (interest); immeru (sheep); kaspu bitqu nuhhutu (scrap silver with 1/8 alloy); maškanu (pledge); puhādu (lamb); ṣalmu (statue)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (26/09/2018)

Main Objects: bīt ṭuppi (school house); bītu (house); broken/unclear; nudunnû (dowry); qallatu (female slave); rašûtu (credit)
Comments: Fragmentary. Old museum no.: Sp II 164 + 769 + 925 + Sp III 576. Van Driel suggests that this fragmentary document might concern property left to Itti-Nabû-balāṭu and Ubāru by their mother.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (26/09/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); rašûtu (credit); zittu (share)

Main Objects: alpu (bull, ox); bābu (sluice); bīt qašti (bow land); bīt ritti (type of land); duhnu (millet); ebūru kūṣu u gumat (winter and summer crops); hallūru (chickpea); kakkû (lentil); kasû (mustard-seed); kibtu (wheat); kunāšu (emmer); mayāru šuhhānu (plough yoked with two oxen); nāru (canal, river); šamaškillu (onion); šamaššammū (sesame); šilihtu (part of canal); šūmū (onions, garlic); sūtu (fixed rent); uṭṭatu (barley); zēru (arable land)
Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (26/09/2018)

Subtype: promissory note, with pledge and without interest
Main Objects: bīt qašti (bow land); eqlu zaqpu u pî šulpi (field planted with palm trees and grain); maškanu (pledge); suluppū (dates); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: Aramaic epigraph: visible but illegible.
Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (27/09/2018)

Main Objects: bīt kamari (house with a ramp); bītu (house); kamaru (ramp); kaspu qalû šibirtu (refined silver in pieces); kunukku (sealed tablet); šīmu (price)
Comments: This is a purchase of real estate within the Gallābu family. Altogether more than 7 members of the family own houses and/or ramps next to each other in this area. The house in question was measured out 3 times.     The tablet is said to be sealed on the upper, left, and right edge (line numbering follows the publication), but the copy shows no seal impressions, while the nail marks on the edges are clearly visible. Most of the seal captions and fingernail mark captions can't be assigned to specific individuals with certainty, as they only consist of personal names (without patronyms and family names) - moreover, the captions also refer to some homonymous individuals (e.g. three persons are called Nidinti-Sîn).
Author: Julia Giessler (27/09/2018)

Main Objects: dīnu (lawsuit); eqlu (field); kaspu (silver); ragāmu (contestation); šipirtu (letter order; message); zēru zaqpu u pî šulpi (land planted with palm trees and grain)
Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (27/09/2018)

Main Objects: idū (rent); makkūr šarri (crown land); sūtu (fixed rent); uṭṭatu (barley); zēru (arable land)
Comments: Aramaic epigraph (inked on reverse): ‘Document pertaining to Bēl-barak and Marduk-ēṭir, sons of B[ēl- ittannu], 200 kurrus of barley - rent [that has been?] ˹paid˺.

Comments: Lessee Hilitī is leasing his own land holding from Enlil-šumu-iddin/Murašû for a period of three years.
Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (27/09/2018)

Main Objects: alpu ummānu (mature ox); bābu (sluice); bīt ritti (type of land); ebūru (harvest); hallūru (chickpea); kasû (mustard-seed); kibtu (wheat); kunāšu (emmer); maškattu (storehouse); mayāru (plough); nāru (canal, river); šamaššammū (sesame); šilihtu (part of canal); šūmū (onions, garlic); uṭṭatu (barley); zēru (arable land)
Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (27/09/2018)

Main Objects: bīt qašti (bow land); bītu (house); ilku (corvée); nadānātu (tribute, due, delivery or 'donations to be paid'); unspecified prebend; zēru zaqpu u pî šulpi (land planted with palm trees and grain); zittu (share)
Comments: This text is about agricultural land, located in the bow land formerly held by Iqīšāya/Sîn-iddin//Gallābu and his replacements, and about a prebend formerly held by him and his brother Šamaš-iddin. Iqīšāya's descendants Sîn-ahu-ušebši and his brother Sîn-abu-uṣur/Sîn-uballiṭ?//Gallābu, and Sîn-ahhē-bulliṭ and his brother Sîn-ušallim/Balāṭu//Gallābu will share it and/or bear the royal taxes jointly.   The lower part of the tablet is not preserved.  The tablet is said to be sealed on the left edge (line numbering follows the publication), but the copy shows no seal impressions, while the nail marks on the upper edge are clearly visible.
Author: Julia Giessler (27/09/2018)

Comments: The document lists the witnesses who were present when Aplāya showed the promissory note according to which Iqīšāya was the debtor. The promissory note had caused trouble because it had Iqīšāya/Kudurru//Egibi as a debtor when Iqīšāya/Kudurru//Nūr-Sîn was meant. The document does not mention a scribe.
Author: Maarja Seire (04/10/2018)

Main Objects: nīšu (oath); not applicable
Comments: The witnesses were present during the statement which Rēmūtu said to Lâbâši. The statement itself is broken. There is also a reference to an oath by Iqīšāya. The document does not mention a scribe.
Author: Maarja Seire (04/10/2018)

Author: Lidewij van de Peut (17/10/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); rašûtu (credit); u’iltu (promissory note); zittu (share)
Comments: This tablet can be attributed to the Ilia A archive. The main protagonist of this archive is Marduk-šumu-ibni. In this tablet he is mentioned as payer of an outstanding debt that his by now deceased father Šulāya, son of Ṣillāya, descendant of Ilia, had with Marduk-šumu-ibni's sister-in-law Nanunu.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (17/10/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); madaktu (expeditionary force, army); šīmu (price); suluppū (dates); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: Sîn-mār-šarri-uṣur, slave (qallu) of the crown prince, lent silver to Tabnēa. The debt had to be repaid in dates to a certain Kīnāya to whom Sîn-mār-šarri-uṣur apparently owed these dates. However, two messengers paid Tabnēa's debt directly to Sîn-mār-šarri-uṣur. This tablet records that Kīnāya will not make any (further) claims about this debt, that he received the owed dates, and that Kīnāya will give the relevant debt notes to Ardia, who is one of the messengers (cf. Ungnad 1937, p. 250 and Dandamayev 1984, p. 335, 393, 403 and 435).
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (17/10/2018)

Comments: The tablet's right half is badly damaged. The preserved text points towards a gift and/or a testament phrased as a dialogue.   The tablet is a copy: it is said to be sealed on the reverse as well as on all edges, but it contains no seal impressions.
Author: Julia Giessler (17/10/2018)

Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ilia A archive. The lower (left) half and the right side of the obverse are broken off. The first half of the reverse is broken off. The preserved obverse part of the tablet mentions 6 neighbouring field owners and 1 owner (?) of a neighbouring canal. The preserved part of the reverse mentions names of individuals (presumably witnesses) after a ruled line. They and the name of the scribe is similar to BM 17657 (Ilia Nbn 13).

Comments: List of property sold; the names of the parties involved are not mentioned.

Comments: Work contract: sluices of obliged party's rivers and canal stretches that are at the Nār-Sîn dam in the karammari area must be reinforced. If Enlil-šumu-iddin's field and those of Ahi-lētī's bow land will be flooded, they will need to compensate.

Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ilia A archive. It records the purchase of land by the main protagonist of this archive Marduk-šumu-ibni, son of Šulāya, descendant of the Ilia family. Cf. BM 17722 (receipt of silver) and BM 17657 (deed of partition - Nbn 13). No seals.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (22/10/2018)

Comments: This tablet can be attributed to the Ilia A archive. The main protagonist of this archive is Marduk-šumu-ibni. He is mentioned in this tablet together with his older brother Nabû-bēlšunu regarding the division of land. The lower and upper edges of the tablet are blank. The reverse which usually contains the list of witnesses and the name of the scribe is almost completely broken off.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (22/10/2018)

Comments: This tablet can be attributed to the Ilia A archive. The main protagonist of this archive is Marduk-šumu-ibni. In this promissory note he is mentioned as creditor of dates together with two of his brothers. The reverse of the tablet is badly damaged.

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: This promissory note has a bond as background: the two debtors guarantee for the presence of Sîn-ahu-iddin, whose female slave shall probably support them (or the creditor respectively). In case Sîn-ahu-iddin (and his slave) should leave, the debtors not only have to pay back the silver to the creditor, but also give him a promissory note, which seems to record a debt of Sîn-ahu-iddin, and thus constitutes the condition, under which he is obliged to stay.   Except for its excavation number, this tablet has no clear connection to the archive.
Author: Julia Giessler (24/10/2018)

Main Objects: guqqû (monthly offering); immeru (mutton); kīṣ ūmi (offerings at the cool of day); niqû ša hazan āli (offerings of the mayor of the city); paspasu (duck); šēru (offering in the morning)
Comments: The operative part of the text is broken off; only a list of offerings and the beginning of the witness list remains.
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (24/10/2018)

Main Objects: karānu (wine, grapes); kurummat šatammūti (ration of the šatammu); nikkassu (account)

Main Objects: Bēltia; lubuštu (clothing festival); Mār-bīti; Marduk; Nabû; Nanāya; Nanāya Ehuršaba; papāhu (a kind of container); Sartu; Sarṭuṭu; siltu (food offering); Sutītu
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (24/10/2018)

Main Objects: bītu (temple); nikkassu (account); suluppū (dates); tēlītu (expenditure); uṭṭatu (barley)

Main Objects: gannu (cut of meat); kaspu (silver); Nanāya Ehuršaba; pēmu (thigh, meat cut); rabû ša šēri (main morning meal); sellu (basket); ṣēlu (rib, meat cut)
Comments: The tablet may be part of the small dossier of Sūqāya/Nabû-nādin-ahi//Ardūtu
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (24/10/2018)

Main Objects: dibbu (dispute); Ezida (temple of Nabû in Borsippa); unspecified prebend
Comments: Dispute about the inheritance or initiation of an adopted priest from Borsippa
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (24/10/2018)

Main Objects: hubuttu (interest-free loan); kaspu (silver)
Comments: The debtor shall pay back to a third man (Šarēdu) in Ur.
Author: Julia Giessler (26/10/2018)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; eqlu (field); maškattu (storehouse); tibnu (straw)
Comments: Fragmentary. Probably a promissory note.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: amēlūtu (slaves); kaspu peṣû (white silver); nudunnû (dowry); qallatu (female slave); šaṭāru (record); ṭuppu (tablet, record); unūtu (utensils)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (29/10/2018)

Subtype: promissory note, with pledge and interest
Main Objects: ebūru (harvest); hubullu (interest); itbaru (colleague (in a business partnership)); kaspu bitqu nuhhutu (scrap silver with 1/8 alloy); maškanu (pledge); qutānu (a narrow strip of field); šīmu (price); u’iltu (promissory note); zēru zaqpu (land planted with date palms); zittu (share)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: Bēl; broken/unclear; hubullu (interest); kaspu peṣû bitqu (white silver with 1/8 alloy)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: bītu (house); mašīhu ša šarri (measure of the king); suluppū (dates)
Comments: The lower left part of the obverse is broken off. The lower edge is blank.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ilia A archive. The main protagonist of this archive is Marduk-šumu-ibni. He is mentioned as payer in this receipt of silver with his alias Ardia.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: gabrû (copy); imittu (assessed rent); suluppū (dates)
Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ilia A archive.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: mār banê (free person); qallatu (female slave)
Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ilia A archive. Cf. VS 5, 37 (Cyr 02), BM 27955 (Cyr 01) and BM 102278 (Camb 01). It is a memorandum of a deposition before the mār banê, characterized by the absence of a scribe.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: bīt išpari (house of the weaver); bīt Nabû (temple of Nabû); eqlu (field); kaspu (silver); rīhtu/rīhitu (remainder, rest); šupāl āli (lower town); tamirtu (irrigated farmland); zēru (arable land); zittu (share)
Comments: This tablet records the receipt of the remainder of the silver to be paid by Marduk-šumu-ibni, son of Šulāya, descendant of the Ilia family, who is the main protagonist of the Ilia A archive, for his purchase of land from his brother Nabû-bēlšunu. This tablet could belong to the sale document BM 26532 and a deed of partition BM 17657.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: eqlu zaqpu (field planted with palm trees); hanšû (hanšû-land); kišubbû (unbuilt land, fallow land); tamirtu (irrigated farmland); zēru (arable land)
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: hanšû (hanšû-land); imittu (assessed rent); suluppū (dates); u’iltu (promissory note)
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: idū (wages); kaspu (silver); ruqqu (cauldron); siparru (bronze)
Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ilia A archive.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: ahu (half); atûtu (doorkeeper’s prebend); bāb nērebi ša Nabû (entrance gate of Nabû); bīt kāri (house at the harbor); bīt Nabû (temple of Nabû); Ezida (temple of Nabû in Borsippa); irbu (income); kaspu (silver); qīštu (gift)
Comments: This tablet can be attributed to the Ilia A archive. The main protagonist Marduk-šumu-ibni, son of Šulāya, descendant of the Ilia family bought his cousin's share of a gatekeeper's prebend for silver. It is a purchase disguised as a gift. Cf. TMH 2/3, 4 (HS 448).
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu peṣû bitqu (white silver with 1/8 alloy); kurummatu (ration); Nabû; ṣibtu ša takkasî (loaf of bread); šikaru (beer); šīru (meat); tilimtu (container); uṭṭatu (barley)
Comments: Lease of sacrificial income
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: ginû (regular offering); rabû ša kīṣ ūmi (main meal served at the cool of day); rabû ša šēri (main morning meal); ṭābihūtu (butcher’s prebend); tardennu ša kīṣ ūmi (second meal served at the cool of day); tardennu ša šēri (second meal of the morning)
Comments: Undated list of days of the butcher's prebend
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: bīt Ea (temple of Ea); muṣīptu (garment); ramāk mê (cleaning); šaddu (basket); šutummu (temple workshop); udû (utensil)
Comments: Attribution to Iddin-Papsukkal B archive is uncertain; Waerzeggers 2010, p. 685
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: Bēlētu; dannu (vat); Ištar-bīti; kanīku (container); kapru (beer offering); Lammu; Mār-bīti; maštītu (beer offering); Nanāya; šibirru (deified sceptre); tilimtu (container)
Comments: List of beer offerings to gods in Borsippa
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (29/10/2018)

Main Objects: bīt kutalli (rear house); bītu (house); eqlu (field); hubullu (interest); idū (rent); kaspu peṣû bitqu nuhhutu (white scrap silver with 1/8 alloy); maškanu (pledge)
Comments: Strassmaier's copy (Dar 579) is incomplete. Only line 1-6 from the obverse are given. For the remainder of the text we follow a transliteration made by Geers (?) which was found in the Van Driel files (Leiden).
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (30/10/2018)

Main Objects: biltu ša huṣābi (load of palm-frond ribs); broken/unclear; eqlu (field); gipû (date basket); imittu (assessed rent); suluppū (dates); tuhallu (palm-leaf basket)
Comments: Very fragmentary.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (30/10/2018)

Main Objects: amēlūtu (slaves); kaspu (silver); nudunnû (dowry); udê bīti (household utensils)
Comments: The assignment to the archive Ea-eppes-ili A follows Jursa 2005. The main protagonist of the Ea-eppēš-ilī C archive gives/promises the dowry, so one could also consider this text as belonging to that archive.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (30/10/2018)

Main Objects: adannu (deadline, term); kaspu (silver); nisihtu; suluppū (dates)
Comments: Šiṭā needs to deliver as many dates as are levied on him from Enlil-šumu-iddin's nisihtu tax of year 38, in full, in the year 39.   Aramaic epigraph (lo.e.): šṭr šyṭˀ br ˹nbw˺d˹yn˺ = ‘Document pertaining to Šiṭā, son of Nabû-dayyānu’.
Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (30/10/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); kaspu ša nadāni u mahāri (silver for trading)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (30/10/2018)

Main Objects: alpu ummānu (mature ox); bīt qašti (bow land); broken/unclear; ebūru (usufruct); ēburu uṭṭati u ṣahhari (main cereal crop and minor crop); immeru (sheep); kasû (mustard-seed); kibtu (wheat); kunāšu (emmer); maddattu (rent, compensation); miṣru (border); mû (water); mūṣû ša šarri (royal land irrigated from special outlets of a canal); nāru (canal, river); qātu ša qitû (bundle of (unspun) flax); sahlû (cress); šamaššammū (sesame); šilihtu (part of canal); sūtu (fixed rent); unūtu (utensils); uṭṭatu (barley); zēru (arable land)
Comments: This lease contract has two separate lessees of distinct objects. They are both servants of lessor Enlil-šumu-iddin. Bēl-aplu-iddin leases a stretch of the Bēl-abu-uṣur canal, 20 plough oxen, utensils, and seeding cereals (ll.1-6); Nabû-ušēzib leases Nār-Natūnu and the left side of Nār-Sîn, 40 plough oxen, utensils, and seeding cereals (ll.7-11). They do, however, guarantee payment for each other.
Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (30/10/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu bitqu nuhhutu (scrap silver with 1/8 alloy); kaspu qalû (refined silver)
Comments: Zawadzki 2022 (NABU 2022/34) notes that this is the last known attestation of Itti-Marduk-balāṭu of the Egibi family but it is uncertain whether the Itti-Marduk-balāṭu mentioned in this tablet corresponds to that man. He is more likely to be equated with Itti-Marduk-balāṭu son of  Bēl-ahhē-iddin of the Nūr-Sîn family.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (30/10/2018)

Main Objects: \N
Comments: See BM 26475; BM 82799 was published by MacGinnis 1991-1992, no. 13, it is now joined to BM 26525.
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (31/10/2018)

Main Objects: bītu (house); erṣet kasīri (kasīru district); idū (rent); maṣṣartu (duty, service; guarding); mūtaq Nergal (thoroughway of Nergal); šaṭāru (record)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (31/10/2018)

Main Objects: ahu (half); kaspu (silver); rē’i alpūtu (oxherd’s prebend)
Comments: Sale of a half-share of an oxherd prebend.
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (31/10/2018)

Main Objects: adannu (deadline, term); dīnu (lawsuit); pūt šēpê (warranty); qanû (plot of land); u’iltu (promissory note)
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (31/10/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); musēniqtu (wet nurse); šīmu (price)
Comments: Urki-šarrat is employed as a wet nurse for the daughter of Ardia. For her services Ardia will pay silver to her father Nabû-nakuttu-alsi.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (31/10/2018)

Main Objects: idū (wages); musēniqtu (wet nurse)
Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ilia A archive. The main protagonist of this archive is mentioned as payer.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (31/10/2018)

Main Objects: šūmū (onions, garlic)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); qaqqadu (capital); šūmū (onions, garlic)

Comments: The document records several transactions.
Author: Maarja Seire (01/11/2018)

Main Objects: hubullu (interest); kaspu bitqu (silver with 1/8 alloy)
Author: Maarja Seire (01/11/2018)

Main Objects: šipirtu (letter order; message); šūmū (onions, garlic); tahsistu lā mašê (memorandum)
Comments: Iddin-Marduk wrote to Nabû-ēṭir and Nādinu to give the onions to Arad-Bēl and Nabû-aplu-iddin. Then the onions were given to Zababa-ahu-iddin. The tablet is a memorandum that says that Arad-Bēl and Nabû-aplu-iddin have received the onions on behalf of Iddin-Marduk and 18000 strings of onions belong to Šūzubu.
Author: Maarja Seire (01/11/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); maddattu (rent, compensation); šikittu (onion field); šūmū (onions, garlic); utru (profit); zittu (share)
Author: Maarja Seire (02/11/2018)

Main Objects: giṭṭu (receipt); hubullu (interest); kaspu peṣû (white silver); maškanu (pledge); u’iltu (promissory note); zēru zaqpu u pî šulpi (land planted with palm trees and grain)
Comments: On the edges there are impressions of 7 stamp seals, probably from the 7 judges.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (02/11/2018)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; harrānu (business venture); šūmū (onions, garlic)
Comments: The document relates to a harrānu business partnership but is essentially a promissory note. According to this document, Nabû-ušallim becomes the sole titleholder.

Main Objects: bītu (house); hubullu (interest); kaspu (silver); rīhtu/rīhitu (remainder, rest); šīmu (price)
Comments: The silver is part of a purchase price of a house, which the debtors lent from the creditor.
Author: Maarja Seire (02/11/2018)

Main Objects: \N
Comments: See the duplicate BM 30506 (Wunsch 1993b, no. 135).
Author: Maarja Seire (02/11/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); kurummatu (ration); makkūru (treasury, estate); Nabû
Comments: Damaged; difficult to read. Attribution to Rē'i-alpi archive uncertain.
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (02/01/2018)

Main Objects: karû (property held in common); kaspu (silver); kirî gišimmarī zaqpu (planted date palm grove); kurummatu (ration); makkūru (treasury, estate); Marduk; mimma ša āli u ṣēri (whatever sb owns in town and country); Nabû; nudunnû (dowry); qanû (plot of land)
Comments: Two seal impressions on the right hand edge of the tablet.

Main Objects: idū (rent); kaspu (silver); rīhtu/rīhitu (remainder, rest)

Main Objects: amēlūtu (slaves); bītu (house); kaspu (silver); nikkassu (account); nudunnû (dowry); qanû (plot of land); šīmu (price); udê bīti (household utensils); zittu (share)
Comments: Receipt of part of the dowry silver promised by Iddin-Marduk to his daughter Nūptāya and her husband Itti-Marduk-balāṭu.
Author: Maarja Seire (02/11/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver)
Comments: Assignment to the Rē'i-alpi archive is uncertain.
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (02/01/2018)

Main Objects: akalu (bread/food); Esagil (temple of Marduk in Babylon); kaspu (silver); Marduk; mimma ša āli u ṣēri (whatever sb owns in town and country); Nabû; qallatu (female slave); Ṣarpanītu; šikaru (beer)
Comments: A man assigns all his property to the sons from a previous marriage, upon re-marrying an ex-slave woman. Two representatives from his first wife's family request this transfer from him, on behalf of the children. The tablet bears no nail marks or sealings.
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (02/01/2018)

Main Objects: bīt qātē (storeroom); Ezida (temple of Nabû in Borsippa); kaspu (silver); qīštu (gift); šutummu (temple workshop)
Comments: Gift of a temple workshop with payment of silver gift.

Comments: Belongs together with BM 26636; purchase made on behalf of Nabû-mukīn-zēri/Aplāya//Rē'i-alpi
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (03/11/2018)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; hubullu (interest); nudunnû (dowry)
Comments: Fragmentary.

Comments: Kohler and Peiser relate this text to BM 77345 = 84-2-11, 79, for which see Kohler and Peiser 1891, pp. 13f.  The list of witnesses is fragmentary.

Main Objects: Emah; hubullu (interest); kaspu nuhhutu (scrap silver); kaspu peṣû bitqu nuhhutu (white scrap silver with 1/8 alloy); maškanu (pledge); Ninmah/Bēlet-ilī; unspecified prebend
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (05/11/2018)

Main Objects: ekurru (temple); Ezida bīt Nabû (temple of Nabû in Borsippa); gullubu (initiated); manzaltu (service period); Marduk; Nabû; rē’i alpūtu (oxherd’s prebend); Ṣarpanītu
Comments: Prebendary work contract with transfer of property rights to a part of the prebend.
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (05/11/2018)

Main Objects: hanšû (hanšû-land); kaspu (silver); kirî gišimmarī zaqpu (planted date palm grove); rašûtu (credit)
Comments: Redemption of property previously sold to absolve debts.

Main Objects: Bēl; bītu (house); broken/unclear; dannu (vat); kasû (mustard-seed); qanû ša abarakku (plot of land of the treasurer); qanû ša Šamaš (plot of land of Šamaš); suluppū (dates); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: The text is related to BM 74645, also written in Sippar. For that text see Roth 1989-1990, p. 52 (no. 7).
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (05/11/2018)

Main Objects: (without specification); bītu (house); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: The document concerns the ownership(?) of Zittāya and her daughter. They are probably slaves, but this is not stated in the text. Their exact relationships towards Aplāya, Šulāya and Ardia is unclear. Arrabu and Nabû-rēṣûa may not contest this arrangement and are liable for Aplāya.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (05/11/2018)

Comments: The main transaction is concerning the silver owed to Iddin-Marduk. A large part of the contract concerns the pledge of the slave by the debtor. The pledged slave belongs to Šumu-iddin, but was pledged to the debtor Ahu-ittabši, who then pledges this slave to Iddin-Marduk. The slave is currently with Bu'ītu. Therefore, the creditor kept this document as pledge instead.

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); muṣīptu (garment); rīhtu/rīhitu (remainder, rest); sartu (stolen property); udû (utensil)
Comments: The first part of this text is styled as a dialogue between Sîn-uballiṭ and Marduk-nāṣir/Nabû-iqīša//Bitahhu: The former says that his stolen goods have been given to the latter by a certain Marduk-zēru-ibni. Marduk-nāṣir admits having bought 3 textiles, but declares that he has not seen the rest of the stolen goods.   The second part of the text is a bond that states what to do about this conflict in the future: If further goods are seen with Marduk-nāṣir, he will be considered a thief. If he meets Marduk-zēru-ibni, he should get his silver back. If Sîn-uballiṭ catches Marduk-zēru-ibni, he will give Marduk-nāṣir back his silver.  According to UET 4 the excavation number of this text is U. 17238, 16, while U. 17238, 39 is the number of the duplicate. But on the hompage of the British museum and CDLI it is the excavation number U. 17238, 39, which is assigned to this text, while the number U. 17238, 16 is not mentioned at all.
Author: Julia Giessler (13/11/2018)

Main Objects: ebūru (harvest); Ezida (temple of Nabû in Borsippa); lē’û (register); makkūru (treasury, estate); Nabû; šamaššammū (sesame); suluppū (dates)

Comments: This tablet can possibly be attributed to the Ilia A archive. Inṣabtu, daughter of Marduk-šumu-iddin, descendant of Ša-nāšišu is attested as creditor of silver. She is the wife of Marduk-šumu-ibni, son of Šulāya, descendant of the Ilia family who is the main protagonist of the Ilia A archive.  The reverse of the tablet is fragmentary. The remainder of the list of witnesses, the name of the scribe, the place and date of writing are broken off or illegible.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (14/11/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); rebû (one fourth); zittu (share)
Comments: This tablet can be attributed to the Ilia A archive. In this receipt Marduk-šumu-ibni, son of Šulāya, descendant of the Ilia family, who is the main protagonist of the Ilia A archive, is attested as payer. The recipient is also the scribe of the tablet.
Author: Evelien Vanderstraeten (14/11/2018)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); maškanu (pledge); qallatu (female slave); šīmu (price)
Comments: The excavation number of this tablet is erroneously also assigned to the copy of UET 4, 55. The list of tablets in this publication renders the excavation numbers correctly (see UET 4, p. 68).     A woman is the debtor of this promissory note, but the silver she borrows is nevertheless specified as the creditor's claim against her husband Sîn-uballiṭ. In case he shouldn't get his silver back before the first day of Month II, he will be entitled to buy the slave girl that he takes as pledge for only 10 shekels of silver.
Author: Julia Giessler (03/01/2019)

An additional clause stating that all the straw belongs to Ṭābia seems to have been added after the text was already entirely written; it is written on the left edge in small script, partly written above the name and title of the king (l.e. 22), and partly below it (l.e.25).
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (07/01/2019)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver)
Comments: The excavation number of this tablet is erroneously also assigned to the copy of UET 4, 14. The list of tablets in this publication renders the excavation numbers correctly (see UET 4, p. 68).  The debtor shall pay back the silver in Babylon, and before day 20 of month XII - otherwise he will have to pay interest.
Author: Julia Giessler (07/01/2019)

Main Objects: abulli Lugal-gìr-ra (Lugal-gìr-ra Gate); bītu epšu (built house); bītu ruggubu (roofed house); daltu (door); kaspu šibirtu (silver in pieces); kunukku (seal); mahīru (market rate); quppu (chest); sikkūru (lock); sippu (doorframe, doorjambs); ṭuppu (tablet, record)
Comments: It is not clear, whether this text really belongs to the archive of Sîn-uballiṭ. It is slightly younger than the other texts, but the recipient of the purchase price of the house is Sîn-zēru-iddin/Ningal-ušēzib, who is well known from this archive.
Author: Julia Giessler (09/01/2019)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (09/01/2019)

Main Objects: Bēl; dīnu (lawsuit); imittu (assessed rent); sahlû (cress); tahsistu lā mašê (memorandum)
Comments: Witnesses (mukinnū ša ina pānišunu) are acting as legal authorities here. The litigants make an oath swearing that they will follow their verdict. The scribe is not mentioned.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (09/01/2019)

Main Objects: broken/unclear
Comments: The scribe is not mentioned. In obv. 2 it is better to read Ṭā[bia u] Ṣillāya than Ṭāb-ṣillâ which was suggested by San Nicolò and Ungnad.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (09/01/2019)

Main Objects: dannu (vat); idū (rent); kaspu (silver); ṭuppu (tablet, record)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (09/01/2019)

Main Objects: (without specification); kaspu (silver); maddattu (rent, compensation)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (09/01/2019)

Main Objects: uṭṭatu (barley)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (09/01/2019)

Subtype: dispute-related; oath; promissory note, with pledge
Main Objects: Bēl; bītu (house); broken/unclear; harrānu (business venture); kaspu (silver); maškanu (pledge); qallu (slave); u’iltu (promissory note); uṭṭatu (barley)
Comments: This remarkable document is a new promissory note which the creditor decided to draw up after a court case had taken place about the owed barley. The debtor also swears an oath that he will not deceive (niklu nakālu) the creditor until he repaid his debt.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (09/01/2019)

Main Objects: biltu ša huṣābi (load of palm-frond ribs); gipû ša uhinni (basket of green dates); gugallu (tax payable to the gugallu); haṣāru (enclosure, storehouse); imittu (assessed rent); kalakku (warehouse, depot); mangāgu (date palm fibres); šissinnu (gardener’s remuneration); suluppū (dates); tuhallu (palm-leaf basket); zittu (share)

Comments: The document concerns dates that are probably owned by or at the disposal of Šūqāya.

Author: Lidewij van de Peut (15/01/2019)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; kaspu (silver)
Comments: Fragmentary.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (15/01/2019)

Main Objects: (without specification); amēlūtu (slaves); kaspu (silver); šīmu (price); ṭuppu (tablet, record); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: This document records an agreement between Nabû-šumu-uṣur and Bābunu. Nabû-šumu-uṣur is obliged to give Bābunu a large amount of silver and Bābunu in turn is obliged to give two slaves (who she had bought from Nabû-ahu-iddin) to Nabû-šumu-uṣur, no matter whether the slaves have died or ran away. The document ends with the remark that afterwards (arki ṭuppi ṭuppi) the slaves will belong to Bābunu.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (15/01/2019)

Main Objects: uṭṭatu (barley)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (15/01/2019)

Comments: BE 9, 22 has received museum number CBS 5388 as well. Possibly, the millet that is being exchanged, is used for the fattening of the birds (CAD I-J p.208).
Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (16/01/2019)

Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (17/01/2019)

Comments: The document lists amounts of silver that are withdrawn (nasāhu) from the harrānu(-account) of Nabû-gāmil.

Main Objects: dannu (vat); gurābu (reinforcement around clay jar); idū (wages); kalakku (warehouse, depot); kasû (mustard-seed); kurummatu (ration); šikaru (beer); sirāšû (brewers); suluppū (dates)

Author: Lidewij van de Peut (17/01/2019)

Main Objects: haṣāru (enclosure, storehouse); kuppu (cistern, water-source); suluppū (dates); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: The document records that the dates that make up the debt of Lē’îtu and her son (debtors) to Ṭābia (creditor) are now at the disposal of Nūrea (obligor) who has to give them to Ṭābia (obligee) in month VIII.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (17/01/2019)

Main Objects: eleppu (boat); suluppū (dates)
Comments: The document records that Nabû-šumu-iddin measured dates delivered to a boat(?) by Nabû-šumu-iškun and Marduk-ibni. No witnesses and no scribe mentioned.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (17/01/2019)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); maddattu (rent, compensation); qallu (slave)
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (17/01/2019)

Author: Rieneke Sonnevelt (17/01/2019)

Main Objects: harrānu (business venture); rašûtu (credit); u’iltu (promissory note); uṭṭatu (barley)
Comments: The document records that Marduk-ēṭir shall not raise a claim against Bulṭāya concerning a promissory note in which he (Marduk-ēṭir) acted as guarantor, because the credit has been paid.

Comments: This tablet can be attributed to the Ilia A + B archive. Marduk-šumu-ibni, son of Šulāya, descendant of Ilia is mentioned as payer of dates.     The right side of the reverse of the tablet is damaged. The obverse of the tablet is complete.

Author: Lidewij van de Peut (22/01/2019)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); rēhu (remainder, outstanding obligation); šīmu (price); ummu eqli (original property deed); zēru (arable land); zēru zaqpu (land planted with date palms)
Comments: The document records a statement that Ṭābia made to Ardia in front of witnesses and Ardia's reply. Ṭābia had already paid Ardia silver as the remainder of the price for a field (zēru) and is now asking for the property deed (ummu eqli) which Ardia had given to Sîn-ilī. Ardia answers him by telling him what to do when a claimant comes before he has given him the property deed.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (22/01/2019)

In addition, Nūrea swears an oath that he will not give the promissory note to anyone else, and that it all belongs to Ṭābia.

Main Objects: bābtu (deficit); bītu (house); idū (rent); kaspu (silver); kāsu siparru (bronze cup); mahīru (market rate); nikkassu (account); šīmu (price); šipirtu (letter order; message); TÚG.KUR.RA (garment); ṭuppu (tablet, record); u’iltu (promissory note); zēru (arable land)
Comments: This document records the following: Ṭābia had bought a field from Nūrea and Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti. Subsequently Nūrea and Lā-qīptu wrote to Ṭābia and the scribe Bēl-nāṣir asking if he did not want to by an additional plot of land so it would add up to 2 PI in total. Ṭābia decides to take an option on this additional field, he drew up a contract, but did not yet pay the silver for the additional plot. Instead he drew up a promissory note which he gave to Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti. If Ṭābia likes the additional plot of land he will pay the silver for it, if he does not like it Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti will return the promissory note to him. An additional clause concerns rent of a house, garments, and cups which Mušēzib-Bēl had taken.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (06/02/2019)

Main Objects: adannu (deadline, term); paqdu (deposit); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: The document records that Bēl-uballiṭ and Mušēzib-Bēl have established a deadline to repay a promissory note and that they considered it a deposit at the disposal of Bulṭāya, in front of witnesses who are designated as mār banê.
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (06/02/2019)

Comments: The document renews one or more previous agreements, which had been lost. Mušēzib-Marduk lost the (purchase) document(s) of the watercourse (tāluku mê) which Bēl-lē’i had bought from Bēlšunu. (Later,) Nergal-ina-tēšî-ēṭir returned the tablet that Mušēzib-Marduk had lost and gave it to Sîn-ilī and his brothers who own the watercourse. Nergal-ina-tēšî-ēṭir owns the trees and date palms alongside the watercourse. This new agreement stipulates that Sîn-ilī and his brothers shall not cut off the water to the field of Nergal-ina-tēšî-ēṭir and that Nergal-ina-tēšî-ēṭir will water the field of Sîn-ilī and his brothers from his canal (harru ša tamirtu Bānītāya).
Author: Lidewij van de Peut (11/02/2019)

Main Objects: qēmu ša hirgalî (hirgalû flour)
Comments: Warranty to grind flour and pay it on behalf of somebody else.
Author: Caroline Waerzeggers (11/02/2019)

Because of this the text subtype and some of the roles assigned to the mentioned individuals are not entirely certain. The document seems to record the partial repayment of a debt of imittu-dates.

Comments: This document is a copy of a broken tablet. This is indicated by the Akkadian word hepû ('broken') which the copyist used quite often. The document is most likely a lease of a slave/baker for work.
Author: Maarja Seire (07/03/2019)

Comments: It is not sure, if this tablet really belongs to the archive of Sîn-uballiṭ. It might have been written in the area of Nippur, as it mentions the governor of Nippur, and probably in the late 7th century, as it mentiones Ulūlāya/Ninurta-iddin, who is also attested in a document from the 5th year of Nabopolassar (UET 4, 202).

Main Objects: kurummatu (ration); lubuštu (clothing); Marduk; piššatu (oil); qallu (slave); Ṣarpanītu; ṭuppi mār banûti (manumission document)
Comments: First, a slave was manumitted on conditions to provide the former owner with rations, oil and clothing. However, he fled and thus failed to meet these conditions. Therefore, his manumission is cancelled, and he is given as a gift to Esagil-ramât (who has been taking care of the donor Iqīšāya) and the ownership rights go to her daughter Nūptāya once Esagil-ramât dies. By being married to Iqīšāya's son Iddin-Marduk, Esagil-ramât is Iqīšāya's daughter-in-law.
Author: Maarja Seire (12/04/2019)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); maškanu (pledge); qallatu (female slave); uṭṭatu (barley)

Main Objects: bītu (house); gišru (bridge); harrānu (business venture); hubullu (interest); kaspu (silver); kaspu bitqu (silver with 1/8 alloy); maškanu (pledge); nudunnû (dowry); qanû (plot of land); qaqqadu (capital); ūru (roof)
Comments: The silver is owed by Ṭābatu and her son Nabû-uballit. They pledge two real estates to the creditor. First one is the house that Ṭābatu had first given to her son. Second one is Ṭābatu's dowry property. The creditor either is or will be living in the house that was first given to Nabû-uballit. The roof of that house has to be fixed in 6 years. The owed silver is invested in Nabû-dāmiq's business.
Author: Maarja Seire (19/04/2019)

Comments: The dowry was originally 24 minas of silver; it entered the estate of Nabû-ahhē-iddin, who has died. According to this document, Itti-Marduk-balāṭu now receives compensation in the shape of a parcel of land that had been purchased from Tabnēa. The remaining debt is for the rest of the silver.  The duplicate is published as Cyr 129.
Author: Maarja Seire (09/05/2019)

Comments: The background of this bond is a joint debt. Upon successive repayment, the debtors pass a receipt or copy of the promissory note on. One of them is now obliged to debit a share for the royal bribe upon his turn. A fourth shareholder (= debtor?) has been brought in.
Author: Julia Giessler (10/05/2019)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; dīnu (lawsuit); Ea; Enlil; kaspu (silver); nišū bīti (people of the household); puhru {{lú}}TIN.TIR{{ki}}.MEŠ {{lú}}BAR.SIP{{ki}}.MEŠ ù {{lú}}ŠEŠ.UNUG{{ki}}.MEŠ (assembly of the Babylonians, Borsippeans and Ureans); šīmu (price); ṭuppu (tablet, record)
Comments: The excavation number U. 20089, 15 might have been assigned to this tablet erroneously, as U. 20089 numbers otherwise refer to the Sîn-ilī (Ur) archive , cf. Jursa 2005, p. 133.  This text is related to UET 4, 27, which is phrased like a dialogue, just like this one, and which records the purchase of Šahītu as a child or young girl. Now she has four children, and a dispute concerning them was raised in the assembly of Babylonians, Borsippeans and Ureans. Then Damqia gave a document (of manumission?) to another Damqia, the son of the former seller Šūzubu. The end of the text and the witness list are badly damaged.
Author: Julia Giessler (27/05/2019)

Comments: The end of the obverse, the beginning of the reverse, and the beginning of the left edge are broken off.  The document records debts owed to Iddin-Marduk and Esagil-ramât. The debtors are Kidin-Marduk, Nabû-mušētiq-uddi and another person whose first name is broken (probably the wife of Kidin-Marduk). At the end of the document, the debt notes are returned to Kidin-Marduk's sons, his brother (co-debtor) and his mother.

Author: Maarja Seire (09/08/2019)

Main Objects: Bēl; bītu (house); broken/unclear; udû (utensil)
Comments: Uhia rents ('lives in') Iddin-Marduk's house. Uhia's husband Kakia and somebody else named Nanāya receive utensils from Iddin-Marduk's grandson Širiktu. They also swear an oath that they have received everything.
Author: Maarja Seire (12/08/2019)

Main Objects: bītu (house); haṣāru (enclosure, storehouse); kaspu (silver); rašûtu (credit); suluppū (dates); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: The document records a debt of dates. The debtor Iddin-Marduk/Niqūdu has to deliver them in two occasions. In addition, the debtor has settled his silver debt to Iddin-Marduk//Egibi. Any promissory notes that turn up in the house of Itti-Marduk-balāṭu, are to be annulled.
Author: Maarja Seire (12/08/2019)

Main Objects: Bēl; immeru (sheep); kaspu (silver); Nabû; šipātu (wool); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: Šaddinnu swears an oath to Marduk-nāṣir-apli, saying that he will bring along his co-debtor's (=Marduk-erība) son Širku, together with the promissory note(s). Note that the document is interpreted in two different ways in NaBuCCo and Wunsch reads it somewhat differently as well.
Author: Maarja Seire (13/08/2019)

Main Objects: bītu (house); broken/unclear; hubuttu (interest-free loan); sūqu Hubur (Hubur street)
Comments: Ina-Esagil-ramât has bought a house with the money she borrowed from Marduk-nāṣir-apli, who now wants the money back. Therefore, Ina-Esagil-ramât brings this case to the collegium of judges. However, they decide, that the house belongs to Marduk-nāṣir-apli, since Ina-Esagil-ramât has not paid him back.
Author: Maarja Seire (13/08/2019)

Main Objects: amēlūtu (slaves); broken/unclear; kaspu (silver); nudunnû (dowry); šaṭāru (record); ṭuppu (tablet, record)
Comments: Ina-Esagil-ramât, the grandmother of Nanāya-ēṭirat, adds 4 minas of silver to her dowry. The document informs that there was already some dowry given by Ina-Esagil-ramât and Itti-Marduk-balāṭu, the father of Nanāya-ēṭirat.
Author: Maarja Seire (13/08/2019)

Main Objects: (without specification); kaspu (silver); nudunnû (dowry); qallu (slave)
Comments: Ina-Esagil-ramât, the grandmother of Nanāya-ēṭirat, is adding a slave to her dowry. This is an addition to silver and two other slaves (specification not mentioned) that were given before. In addition, also Itti-Marduk-balāṭu has already given Nanāya-ēṭirat's dowry to Kurbanni-Marduk.
Author: Maarja Seire (13/08/2019)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); maškanu (pledge); mimma ša āli u ṣēri (pledge of all property); qanû (plot of land); rašûtu (credit); šīmu (price)
Comments: The silver is owed due to the sale of land.
Author: Maarja Seire (13/08/2019)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; eqlu (field); ešrû (tithe); Nergal; šadû (mountain); šibšu (agricultural tax)
Comments: Bīt-ašarra-šarru-uṣur is responsible for collecting the šibšu-tax from the land owners mentioned in the text. The amounts of onions for the tax payments are mentioned as well. All land is located in 'the mountain (ina šadî)'.
Author: Maarja Seire (15/08/2019)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; u’iltu (promissory note)

Comments: The document mentions a sealing, but it is not present on the tablet. The first half of the document describes the purchase of the land by Marduk-ēṭir, and the second part describes how Nabû-ahhē-iddin purchased it from the sons of Marduk-ēṭir. The document is rather fragmentary.    Cf. BM 32640+, BM 48351 and BM 41399.

Comments: The silver owed is part of the dowry of Ninlil-ēṭirat. The debtor is her father-in-law, and he has pledged a part of his land to her. Towards the end another sale document of land is mentioned, but it is not clear whether the document (i.e. in connection with the pledge) or the land was handed over to Ninlil-ēṭirat.
Author: Maarja Seire (5/12/2019)

Main Objects: amēlūtu (slaves); harrān Kiš (road to Kiš); harrān šarri (king's street); kišād Nār-Bānītu (bank of Nār-Bānītu); makallû (mooring place); šaṭāru (record); udê bīti (household utensils); zēru (arable land); zēru zaqpu (land planted with date palms); zittu (share)
Comments: Itti-Marduk-balāṭu fulfilled the dowry promise that his father had made after the latter had died. The five slaves given to Dummuqu were bought from the Nappāhu family. The five slaves mentioned by name will be given to Dummuqu by Qudāšu.

Comments: Settlement of accounts between the sons of the debtors and the creditors. Written on the same day as MMA 79.7.8 (CTMMA 3, no. 57).

Comments: The shares of a property and slaves are divided by casting lots. In addition, other assets that remain undivided are mentioned. Who gets what (i.e. which slaves, which land etc) is not mentioned in this document.

Main Objects: amēlūtu (slaves); bāb Nār-Borsippa (entrance of Nār-Borsippa); ebūru (harvest); giṭṭu (receipt); harrānu (business venture); karû (property held in common by several persons); kaspu (silver); lē’û (register); nikkassu (account); šaṭāru (record); šīmu (price); suluppū (dates); u’iltu (promissory note); zēru zaqpu u pî šulpi (land planted with palm trees and grain); zittu (share)
Comments: Itti-Marduk-balāṭu and Bēlšunu divide the profits and assets of the business partnership of Bēlšunu and Nabû-ahhē-iddin. The latter was Itti-Marduk-balāṭu's father who has passed away. Among the divided assets are slaves, but their designation is not mentioned. In addition to that, the document records that fugitive slaves (amīlūtu) and other assets that may turn up, will remain undivided.
Author: Maarja Seire (15/12/2019)

Main Objects: \N

Main Objects: broken/unclear; gišimmaru (date palm); kaspu (silver); makallû ša hanšê (mooring place of the hanšû-land); ṭuppu (tablet, record); zēru (arable land); zēru mērešu u taptû (grain-cultivated and newly cleared land)
Comments: The document records the need to measure the land after seller Bazuzu's death. Bēl-ahhē-iddin is the heir of Bazuzu and is therefore in position to make an agreement regarding the measurement of the field with the new owner Itti-Marduk-balāṭu.
Author: Maarja Seire (13/01/2019)

Main Objects: biltu ša huṣābi (load of palm-frond ribs); darīku (container); gipû (date basket); haṣāru (enclosure, storehouse); imittu (assessed rent); mangāgu (date palm fibres); suluppū (dates); tuhallu (palm-leaf basket)

It seems like the founders of the business themselves (Nabû-ahhē-iddin and Rēmūtu) have passed away because the profits are divided by their sons.

Comments: The tablet records a payment for the land sold to Itti-Marduk-balāṭu. The buyer pays part of the money to the sellers (a mother and son) - according to the text the silver is given to Nādinu (the son) -, and another part to the creditor of Tašmētu-damqat (the mother).

Comments: This tablet records a transfer of assets from 5 sons to their mother.  According to Wunsch this seems to be a copy of an archival tablet. There are several problems with this text. See Wunsch 2000b, p. 107 and the description of this tablet on NaBuCCo.
Author: Maarja Seire (20/03/2020)

Main Objects: ardu (slave); broken/unclear; dīnu (lawsuit); nudunnû (dowry); šīmu (price); ṭuppu (tablet, record); zēru (arable land); zittu (inheritance share)
Comments: It is a court protocol where the 2 sons of Šumu-ukīn are claiming their ownership over the land and slaves their mother had given them with a sealed document years ago. The king's name is broken in the date formula. In line 2 Wunsch restores: judges of Na[bonidus] (most likely based on prosopography).
Author: Maarja Seire (20/03/2020)

Main Objects: bītu (house); suluppū (dates)

Author: Maarja Seire (21/03/2020)

Main Objects: eqlu (field); harru (canal); kaspu (silver); maškanu (pledge); purussû (decision); ṭuppu (tablet, record); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: The two debtors claim they sold the pledged field to Itti-Marduk-balāṭu's father, but they can't prove it. The debt was for 5 m of silver, the debtors claim they sold it and should get (another) 30 š, but if they cannot prove the sale they have to pay 10 times 5 minas for falsification. See the paraphrase on NaBuCCo.
Author: Maarja Seire (21/03/2020)

Main Objects: \N
Comments: See the duplicate BM 32165+ (Wunsch 2000b, no. 90A). The tablet is unsealed, although the seal descriptions are present (i.e. 'seal of ... the judge').
Author: Maarja Seire (21/03/2020)

Comments: Nabû-bān-ahi acts as a proxy to buy land for Nabû-ahhē-iddin. This document records that the wife of Nabû-ēreš was present, i.e. she gave her consent to this transaction. The land that was sold was part of the dowry of the seller's mother, Kurunnu-tabni.
Author: Maarja Seire (22/03/2020)

Comments: The tablet is very fragmentary. The list of judges is broken but can be restored from the sealings and their descriptions. More judges might have sealed the tablet, as the edges where more sealings could be found are broken.

Author: Ivo Martins (02/04/2020)

Comments: This document is connected to BM 32674+.
Author: Maarja Seire (01/04/2020)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; kaspu (silver); ṭuppi dīni (tablet of the dispute); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: The three sisters (Nadāya, Esagil-ramât and Bēlilitu) sold land to Nabû-ahhē-iddin. Because of the litigation raised by Hibuṣu (BM 31961), the buyer Nabû-ahhē-iddin has to pay (some or whole of the sum) to Hibuṣu and her son instead of the three sisters who were the sellers and therefore expecting the payment according to the original sale document (BM 33056+, published in Wunsch 2000b, no. 111).    The tablet has no sealings, although the text says so.
Author: Maarja Seire (01/04/2020)

Main Objects: ebūru (harvest); eqlu (field); kaspu (silver); šīmu (price); zēru (arable land)
Comments: The tablet belongs to the Pitt Rivers Museum, Oxford.    This is a partial receipt for silver. See BM 33056; BM 31961; BM 31356.
Author: Maarja Seire (01/04/2020)

Main Objects: eqlu (field); kaspu (silver); šīmu (price); u’iltu (promissory note)
Comments: Three sisters sold a field in order to pay their creditor. NaBuCCo identifies them as the daughters of Šamaš-udammiq//Maštukku. This record documents the payment of the field's price by the buyer to the women's creditor.
Author: Maarja Seire (01/04/2020)

Main Objects: broken/unclear; miṣru (border); nudunnû (dowry); rīhtu/rīhitu (remainder, rest); zēru (arable land); zēru pî šulpi (grain-cultivated land)
Comments: The tablet is in private ownership. Wunsch adds that the tablet is poorly written, which could mean that it is a copy of an original.  The document comments on two different purchases, plus land that was already owned by one of the buyers. The sellers agree not to complain about the purchase.
Author: Maarja Seire (01/04/2020)

Subtype: promissory note, with pledge and interest
Main Objects: broken/unclear; dūru (wall); hubullu (interest); kaspu (silver); maškanu (pledge); qaqqadu (capital); zēru (arable land)

Comments: The tablet was written with a slightly split reed and thus many of the wedges, and especially the winkelhaken, seem doubled.

Main Objects: abulli Uraš (Uraš Gate); amēlūtu (slaves); atru (additional payment); bītu (house); eqel ṣēri (open country); eqlu (field); erṣetu (area); harrānu (street); harru (canal); kalû u gabību (land of bad quality); kaspu (silver); kirî gišimmarī zaqpu iṣṣi bilti (grove planted with fruit-bearing date palms); kišubbû (unbuilt land, fallow land); lubāru (garment); mahīru (market rate); maškanu (pledge); pīhat Bābili (district of Babylon); šīmu (price); šuqultu (value); tamirtu (irrigated farmland); taptû (newly cleared land); ugāru (meadowland); zēru (arable land); zēru mērešu (grain-cultivated land)
Comments: The document describes previous purchases of land together with the most recent purchase by Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi. The document mentions the creditors of the sellers as recipients of silver from the sale as well.    The document exists in 2-4 copies, see Wunsch 2000b, no. 125B, Wunsch 2000b, no. 125C, Wunsch 2000b, no. 125D and Wunsch 2000b, no. 125E.     Wunsch also discusses 4 retroacts related to this document. See the discussion and comparisons under Wunsch 2000b, no. 125A. For the retroacts, see BM 31834 (Wunsch 2000b, no. 126), BM 30418 (Wunsch 2000b, no. 127), BM 32115 (Wunsch 2000b, no. 134), BM 32878 (Wunsch 2000b, no. 135).    The join BM 38111 has an entry in cdli: https://cdli.ucla.edu/P507646.    See NaBuCCo for paraphrase.
Author: Maarja Seire (08/04/2020)

Comments: The document also mentions that if the area should be smaller or bigger than agreed upon (i.e. after measurements), the price would be changed according to that. The size of the land is broken.  The witnesses are introduced with ina kanāku ṭuppi šuāti [pāni] (at the sealing of this tablet, present).  The fingernail markings are probably the sellers, but the line mentioning that is broken.

Subtype: promissory note, with pledge and without interest
Main Objects: abulli Giššu (Giššu Gate); bīt maškani (pledged property); kaspu (silver); maškanu (pledge); qaqqadu (capital); u’iltu (promissory note); zēru (arable land)
Author: Maarja Seire (25/04/2020)

Main Objects: kurummatu (ration); qēmu (flour); sahlû (cress); šamnu (oil); ṭabtu (salt)
Author: Laura Dees (27/04/2020)

Main Objects: abulli Giššu (Giššu Gate); būšû (valuables); dibbu (dispute); gišhuru (magic circle); kaspu (silver); makkūru (treasury, estate); maškanu (pledge); muṣīptu (garment); niklu (trick, deception); riksu (agreement); Šamaš; tarkuttu (jewelry(?)); tikip santakki (cuneiform wedge); ṭuppu (tablet, record); u’iltu (promissory note); uṭṭatu (barley); zēru (arable land)
Comments: The tablet records that Nabû-utirri will swear an oath to the gods at the designated time in front of Šamaš, while standing in a magic circle. The oath is sworn to Nādinu and states that Nabû-utirri will have no lawsuit against him and that Nabû-utirri has not committed a fraud. The dispute relates to the handling of the possessions of Nabû-ēreš, who is dead by now. See NaBuCCo for the full paraphrase.
Author: Maarja Seire (30/04/2020)

Main Objects: abulli Zababa (Zababa Gate); kaspu (silver); maškanu (pledge); pīhat Bābili (district of Babylon); qīštu (gift); rašûtu (credit); šaṭāru (record); ṭuppu (tablet, record); ummu eqli (original property deed); zēru (arable land)
Comments: Receipt of a gift of silver in exchange for the ownership rights to a plot of land that had been pledged to an Egibi slave.     Nabû-ēreš has pledged a field that he got from his wife Esagil-bēlet to Nabû-utirri, the slave of Itti-Marduk-balāṭu. In fact, the wife still has the original sale deed(s), which she now gives to the creditor's master, Itti-Marduk-balāṭu, who in return pays Esagil-bēlet a gift of silver.    See the full paraphrase in NaBuCCo.
Author: Maarja Seire (30/04/2020)

Main Objects: abulli Uraš (Uraš Gate); broken/unclear; eqel ṣēri (open country); eqlu (field); eqlu mērešu u taptû (grain-cultivated and newly cleared field); harrān šarri (king's street); kaspu (silver); kaspu šibirtu (silver in pieces); kirî gišimmarī zaqpu iṣṣi bilti (grove planted with fruit-bearing date palms); kišād Nār-Piqūdu (bank of Nār-Piqūdu); mahīru (market rate); makallû ša hanšê (mooring place of the hanšû-land); pīhat Bābili (district of Babylon); šīmu (price); šuqultu (value); ugāru (meadowland); zēru (arable land)
Comments: See BM 30665 (Wunsch 2000b, no. 182) and BM 32907 (Wunsch 2000b, no. 183), which deal with the debts owed due to this purchase. The purchase document is written one day after the promissory note BM 30665. According to that promissory note, the debt has to be paid in two installments months later, in Nisan (month I) and in Simān (month III). However, see also promissory note BM 32907, which records that the debt was not paid even two years later.
Author: Maarja Seire (01/05/2020)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); rīhtu/rīhitu (remainder, rest); šīmu (price); uṭṭatu (barley); zēru (arable land)
Comments: Debt owed for the purchase of land. See BM 32895+ (Wunsch 2000b, no. 181A) for the purchase document. The purchase document is written one day after this promissory note. According to this promissory note, the debt has to be paid in two installments months later, in Nisan (month I) and in Simān (month III). However, see also BM 32907 (Wunsch 2000b, no. 183), which records that the debt was not paid even two years later.

Comments: A sale of a slave woman and the son that she bore. The slave woman was first pledged for a debt of silver, and now sold. CTMMA 3, no. 48 shows that this was a proxy sale for Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi.
Author: Maarja Seire (04/09/2020)

Main Objects: angurennu parzillu (iron lamp stand); dannu (vat); eršu (bed); harrānu (business venture); kaspu (silver); kaspu qallalu (silver in small pieces); kāsu siparru (bronze cup); kussû (chair); marru parzillu (iron spade); mušahhinu (cooking vessel); namharu (collecting vat); namzītu (fermenting vat); nashiptu parzillu (iron shovel); qulmû parzillu (iron axe); šikaru ṭābu (full-strength beer); suluppū (dates); u’iltu (promissory note)
Author: Maarja Seire (04/09/2020)

Main Objects: ahu (half); harrānu (business venture); kaspu (silver); mimma mala ina āli u ṣēri (profits in town and countryside); muṣīptu (garment); qaqqadu (capital); utru (profit); zittu (share)
Comments: Marduk-šāpik-zēri//Nādin-še’i was a business partner of Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi. According to CTMMA 3, many tablets mentioning Marduk-šāpik-zēri belong to the 76-11-17 accession group - therefore, a part of his dossier was kept in the Egibi archive. See CTMMA 3, p. 106.
Author: Maarja Seire (06/09/2020)

Main Objects: kaspu (silver); maddattu (rent, compensation); maškanu (pledge); qallatu (female slave)
Comments: The silver is for the hire of a slave woman Sinūnu, who is possibly a slave woman of Banât-Esagil at this point. In Nbn 400 (duplicate Nbn 509), written 5 years later, Sinūnu is sold together with her husband Lūmur-dumqi-bāni and their daughter Ina-bāb-magāri-alsišu. The buyer is Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi. 24 days after this sale, another document is drafted that records four more witnesses being present while Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi bought Sinūnu, her husband, their daughter and another 3 slaves (BM 30652 = Wunsch 1993b, no. 184).
Author: Maarja Seire (06/09/2020)

Main Objects: not applicable
Comments: Nabû-ahhē-iddin adopts the child of his sister. See the comment in CTMMA 3, p. 110.
Author: Maarja Seire (06/09/2020)
